block.p: Car Bomb in Baghdad Kills 5 and Wounds 24 A car bomb tore through a restaurant in Baghdad filled with dozens of New Year's Eve revelers, killing at least five people and wounding 24, including three Americans. The bombing capped a bloody day in the capital and in other parts of Iraq.

Confidence Vote on Musharraf President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan will face a vote of confidence by the electoral college that would allow him to stay president until 2007. There is little doubt that he will win, but many members of the opposition parties have indicated they would abstain from voting.

Car Bomb in Baghdad Kills 5 and Wounds 24 A car bomb tore through a restaurant in Baghdad filled with dozens of New Year's Eve revelers, killing at least five people and wounding 24, including three Americans. The bombing capped a bloody day in the capital and in other parts of Iraq.

Confidence Vote on Musharraf President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan will face a vote of confidence by the electoral college that would allow him to stay president until 2007. There is little doubt that he will win, but many members of the opposition parties have indicated they would abstain from voting.

Afghan Constitution in Trouble Afghanistan's constitutional convention continued in deadlock. Ethnic divisions were aggravated as each side raised more objections, throwing the entire constitution into question.

Israeli Plan Angers Syria Israel confirmed plans for a major expansion of Jewish settlements in the Golan Heights, angering Syria, from which the territory was seized in 1967. Officials said the plan had been in the works for months and denied that it was intended as a response to a call for renewed peace talks.

Iran's Orphaned Children Rescue workers, no longer searching for survivors of the earthquake in Iran, are turning to many other challenges. Among them are the special needs of the more than 1,200 orphaned children. A team of psychologists and psychiatric workers was sent to help the suddenly parentless begin to cope.

Iranians have expressed mixed emotions about the presence of a United States team in the relief effort, especially after a series of mishaps delayed their arrival. The team will work with the Iranian Red Crescent to help assess the damage and draw up a list of needs for donors.

U.S.-Bound Flight Forced Back to Mexican Airport American authorities ordered a United States-bound flight from Mexico to turn around in midair and imposed extraordinary security measures on at least six other incoming flights because of terrorist concerns, officials said.

Cattle Lobby Ready for Fight When word flashed to the National Cattlemen's Beef Association that the first case of mad cow disease in the United States had been found on the West Coast, it was a red alert for an industry that spent years playing down the threat.

Terror Suspects' Motives United States authorities are trying to learn whether two American brothers detained in the Philippines on terrorism charges were in fact providing support to Islamic militants, officials said.

Rehnquist Criticizes Congress Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist criticized Congress for a recent law that places federal judges under special scrutiny for sentences that fall short of those called for by sentencing guidelines.
Searching for Missing Online A growing coalition of amateur and semiprofessional cybersleuths are using the internet to find the vanished and put names to the unidentified.

John Gregory Dunne The novelist, journalist, and screenwriter who wrote best-selling novels and acclaimed works of nonfiction crammed with pungent dialogue, lavish brutality and glimpses of the Hollywood demimonde, he was 71.

Study Clears the Way For More Taxicabs Results of a recent impact study have helped clear the way for the largest taxicab-fleet expansion in New York City in 70 years. Though it concluded that adding 900 cabs would not pose environmental concerns, the proposal, which is subject to public hearings, will bring the city millions of dollars but require traffic signal changes and a slight fare increase.

Terror Threat Greets New Year A Code Orange Alert, issued Dec. 21 by the Department of Homeland Security, has generated the tightest New Year's security controls since the millennium concerns of 2000.
For revelers in Times Square, the New Year's Eve countdown was about party, not panic.

Evaluating 9/11 Relief Kenneth R. Feinberg, the administrator of the federal program to compensate the relatives of Sept. 11 victims, painted a mixed portrait of the government effort that has resulted in 97 percent of all eligible families agreeing not to sue the airlines or federal agencies, and instead filing claims with the program.

More Scrutiny of Rowland Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut personally sponsored for state jobs children of a partner in a private development project, according to a governor's office log. A spokesman for the governor said the jobs were awarded strictly on merit.
Wells to Leave Yankees Left-handed pitcher David Wells walked away from an oral commitment with the Yankees to sign a one-year, $1.25 million contract with the San Diego Padres.

Stocks End Three-Year Slump Though the highs of 2000 are still out of reach, stocks broke a three-year slide in 2003, as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 25 percent and the Nasdaq composite index climbed 50 percent.

Parmalat Executives Detained Italian police detained seven executives and advisers of Parmalat and were seeking an eighth in the investigation of events that led to the company's collapse under about $11 billion of liabilities.
Top Earners Were Top Givers The top 400 American earners in 2000 provided nearly 7 percent of all the charitable gifts reported on income tax returns for that year.
Editorials: New Year's wishes, revised; between the years.
